abstract.t: This document captures consensus on operational state requirements by the NETMOD working group.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

The following terms are defined in :
intended configuration - this data represents the state that the network operator intends the system to be in. This data is colloquially referred to as the 'configuration' of the system. applied configuration - this data represents the state that the network element is actually in, i.e., that which is currently being run by particular software modules (e.g., the BGP daemon), or other systems within the device (e.g., a secondary control- plane, or line card). derived state - this data represents information which is generated as part of the system's own interactions. For example, derived state may consist of the results of protocol interactions (the negotiated duplex state of an Ethernet link), statistics (such as message queue depth), or counters (such as packet input or output bytes).

list.t:
Ability to interact with both intended and applied configuration
The ability to ask the operational components of a system (e.g., line cards) for the configuration that they are currently using. This is the "applied configuration". Applied configuration is read-only The data model for the applied configuration is the same as the data model for the intended configuration (same leaves) For asynchronous systems, when fully synchronized, the data in the applied configuration is the same as the data in the intended configuration.

Applied configuration as part of operational state
The ability to retrieve the applied configuration and derived state nodes in a single protocol operation.

Support for both transactional, synchronous management systems as well as distributed, asynchronous management systems
For asynchronous systems, the ability to request a protocol operation to not return (i.e. block) until the intended configuration has been fully synchronized. The protocol operation's response would indicate the result of the operation (success, failure, partial, etc.)

Separation of configuration and operational state data; ability to retrieve them and independently
Be able to retrieve only the derived state aspects of operational state Be able to retrieve only the non-derived state aspects of operational state

Ability to relate configuration with its corresponding operational state
Ability to map intended config nodes to corresponding applied config nodes Ability to map intended config nodes to associated derived state nodes The mappings needs to be programmatically consumable

Ability for distinct modules to leverage a common model-structure
Focus on the IETF-defined modules, and ideally provides guidance to other SDOs Multiple domain-specific model-structure trees are okay Model-structures may be defined in multiple modules with distinct namespaces
